page.title: 11GEDDINGTON PARISH CHURCH
page.content: The Church of St. Mary Magdalene was originally built in AD 900. Evidence of Saxon building exists in the line of the steep pitched thatched roof over the Chancel arch and the infilled arched windows above the arches on the North side. In the North aisle above the Norman arches are traces of a Saxon arcade dating back to AD 950. On the North wall is the King's Door by which the Medieval Kings would enter the Church when staying at the Royal Hunting Lodge. On the floor is a brass commemorating John Mulso and his wife Joan Tresham, and an alebaster slab depicting Richard Tresham and his wife Isabel. Further evidence of the Tresham Family is the Tudor Oak screen in the South aisle. The present incumbant is the Reverend Thomas Wolfendon.
